introduction: Throughout his career spanning over six decades, Magnús Pálsson worked in various studio spaces across Reykjavík and internationally. These workspaces were integral to his creative process, from the early conceptual works and plaster sculptures to later sound poetry and performance pieces.

This chronological documentation shows the evolution of his working environments, each reflecting different phases of his artistic development and the practical needs of his diverse practice encompassing sculpture, performance, sound art, theater, and teaching.

studios.title: Vesturgata 45 - Early Architectural Work
paragraphs: Early workshop at Vesturgata 45 where Magnús Pálsson collaborated with Dieter Roth creating architectural models of public buildings. This workspace represents the beginning of his professional practice and his important early collaboration with the influential German artist who would become a lifelong friend and collaborator.

studios.title: Sólvallagata 3
paragraphs: Home and studio.Studio workspace at Sólvallagata 3, adding to the network of Reykjavík locations where Magnús Pálsson developed his artistic practice across different periods of his career.

studios.title: Hvarf - Garage Studio

images.alt: Hvarf garage studio - working space before fire
Hvarf garage studio - garage structure with main house windows visible in background
Hvarf garage studio - materials and work area

paragraphs: The garage at Hvarf was converted into studio space from 1962, providing practical workspace for larger projects and material storage. These rare black and white photographs document the actual working garage before it was destroyed by fire in 1969, showing the rustic but functional space where important artworks were created. This studio was active during the entire Bestu stykkin period (1965-1967) and where the controversial cloth figure series was actually created, making it the birthplace of Magnús Pálsson's most provocative early work.

studios.title: Grundarstígur Shared Studio
paragraphs: Shared studio space on Grundarstígur with sculptor Ragnar Kjartansson and visiting artist Dieter Roth. This collaborative environment was crucial for Magnús Pálsson's development, particularly his experiments with plaster casting techniques and conceptual art approaches. The shared workspace fostered important artistic exchanges and influenced his material practices.

studios.title: Skólavörðustígur 3
paragraphs: Studio space at Skólavörðustígur 3, located on one of Reykjavík's most central streets. This location places the studio in the heart of the city's cultural district, near galleries, shops, and the iconic Hallgrímskirkja church.

studios.title: Hvarf - Main House
paragraphs: Home and studio.The main house at Hvarf served as both residence and studio space, providing a rural environment for artistic work away from the city. This location offered different creative possibilities and working conditions from his urban studios.

studios.title: Mile End Place, London
paragraphs: Home and studio.International studio space in East London's Mile End area, representing Magnús Pálsson's connections to the broader European art scene and providing a base for his work in the UK art community.

studios.title: Collage Road, London
paragraphs: Home and studio.Another London studio location that provided workspace during Magnús Pálsson's periods in the UK, further demonstrating his international artistic connections and cross-cultural practice.

studios.title: Brautarholt 18
paragraphs: Studio space at Brautarholt 18, representing a significant period in Magnús Pálsson's later career. This workspace supported his continued artistic production during a mature phase of his practice, encompassing sound poetry, performance, and installation work.

studios.title: Þingholtsstræti 30 Studio
paragraphs: Home and studio.Working studio at Þingholtsstræti 30 featuring extensive shelving systems for organized storage of works, materials, and documentation. The studio combines active workspace with methodical archival organization, reflecting Magnús Pálsson's systematic approach to both creating and preserving his artistic output.

studios.title: Vesturgata Studio

images.alt: Vesturgata studio exterior - distinctive turquoise corrugated building

paragraphs: The distinctive turquoise corrugated metal building with yellow window trim housed one of Magnús Pálsson's most productive studio periods. The space featured a central courtyard and multiple rooms suitable for both sculptural work and storage of materials.

studios.title: Mýrargata Studio
paragraphs: Located on Mýrargata in Reykjavík's arts district, this modern building provided studio space during a period of increased collaboration with other artists and institutions. The area became a hub for contemporary art activity in the city.

studios.title: Freyjugata 17B
paragraphs: Home and studio.A classic Reykjavík wooden house that served as both residence and studio space. The traditional Icelandic architecture provided an intimate working environment suited to smaller-scale projects and detailed work.

studios.title: Nauthólsvík
paragraphs: Studio space in the Nauthólsvík area, providing a different working environment for specific projects and periods of artistic development.

studios.title: Klapparstígur 22
paragraphs: Studio space at Klapparstígur 22 during a transitional period in his career. This location provided workspace during the development of his later artistic phases, bridging between his experimental 1980s work and his mature sound poetry period of the 1990s-2000s.

studios.title: Óðinsgata - Back House
paragraphs: Studio space in the back house on Óðinsgata. Further details about this workspace period and its role in Magnús Pálsson's practice to be researched through conversations with Borghildur Óskarsdóttir and other sources.

studios.title: Ásmundarsalur - Myndhöggvarafélag Space
paragraphs: Earlier workspace at Ásmundarsalur where the Icelandic Sculptors' Association (Myndhöggvarafélag Íslands) maintained studio facilities before moving to Korpúlfsstaðir. This historic location is significant as it's also where Magnús Pálsson held his controversial debut solo exhibition "Bestu stykkin" in 1967, making it both a working space and exhibition venue in his career.

studios.title: Korpúlfsstaðir - Myndhöggvarafélag Space
paragraphs: Later workspace at Korpúlfsstaðir where the Icelandic Sculptors' Association (Myndhöggvarafélag Íslands) maintained studio facilities after relocating from Ásmundarsalur. This collective space provided access to specialized equipment and a community of sculptors, supporting Magnús Pálsson's sculptural practice and fostering connections with fellow artists.

studios.title: Iðnó Theater
paragraphs: Workspace at Iðnó, one of Reykjavík's important theaters, where Magnús Pálsson developed stage designs and theater productions. Iðnó has been central to Icelandic cultural life and experimental theater.

studios.title: Þjóðleikhúsið (National Theatre) Workspace
paragraphs: Workspace at Þjóðleikhúsið (National Theatre) on Hverfisgötu, reflecting his extensive career in stage design and theater production. This institutional workspace provided access to professional theater facilities and collaboration with directors, actors, and other theater professionals.

context.title: Studio Practice & Creative Process
paragraphs: Magnús Pálsson's choice of studio spaces reflected his evolving artistic needs:

The chronological documentation shows how each workspace was adapted to support his multidisciplinary practice, from traditional sculpture to experimental performance and conceptual art projects, spanning over six decades of creative evolution.
list: Plaster work period- Spaces with good ventilation and concrete floors for casting
Sound poetry development- Quiet areas for recording and acoustic experimentation
Teaching collaborations- Accessible spaces for student workshops and group projects
Archive maintenance- Organized storage systems for preserving decades of work
